data.chText: 几乎不；几乎没有
data.enText: almost no; almost not; almost none

data.chText: 没有剩什么茶了。
data.enText: There's hardly any tea left.

data.chText: 几乎没人动嘴回答。
data.enText: Hardly anyone has bothered to reply.

data.chText: 她几乎从未给我来过电话。
data.enText: She hardly ever calls me (= almost never) .

data.chText: 我们彼此还不大认识呢。
data.enText: We hardly know each other.

data.chText: 我几乎天天想着她。
data.enText: Hardly a day goes by without my thinking of her (= I think of her almost every day) .

data.chText: （尤用于can或could之后，主要动词之前，强调做某事很难）
data.enText: used especially after ‘can’ or ‘could’ and before the main verb, to emphasize that it is difficult to do sth

data.chText: 我困得都快睁不开眼了。
data.enText: I can hardly keep my eyes open (= I'm almost falling asleep) .

data.chText: 读到那封信时，我简直不敢相信。
data.enText: I could hardly believe it when I read the letter.

data.chText: 刚刚；才
data.enText: used to say that sth has just begun, happened, etc.

data.chText: 现在不能停下来喝咖啡，我们刚刚才开始工作呢。
data.enText: We can't stop for coffee now, we've hardly started.

data.chText: 我们刚坐下用晚餐，电话就响了。
data.enText: We had hardly sat down to supper when the phone rang.

data.chText: 话刚出口，她就后悔不迭。
data.enText: Hardly had she spoken than she regretted it bitterly.

data.chText: （表示不大可能、不合理或愚蠢）
data.enText: used to suggest that sth is unlikely or unreasonable or that sb is silly for saying or doing sth

data.chText: 他不大可能承认自己错了。
data.enText: He is hardly likely to admit he was wrong.

data.chText: 她被解雇了不足为怪，她从来没干过任何工作。
data.enText: It's hardly surprising she was fired; she never did any work.

data.chText: 现在还不是讨论的时候。
data.enText: It's hardly the time to discuss it now.

data.chText: 你不可能指望她无偿地做这事。
data.enText: You can hardly expect her to do it for free.

data.chText: “你不能就说声不吗？”“喔，不可能，她是我小姨子。”
data.enText: ‘Couldn't you have just said no?’ ‘Well, hardly, (= of course not) she's my wife's sister.’

data.chText: 形容词hard的副词为hard：
data.enText: The adverb from the adjective hard is hard .

data.chText: 今天我得努力工作。
data.enText: I have to work hard today.

data.chText: 她曾经悉心思考她未来的计划。
data.enText: She has thought very hard about her future plans.

data.chText: 外面雨下得很大。
data.enText: It was raining hard outside.

data.chText: hardly为副词，意为几乎不、几乎没有：
data.enText: Hardly is an adverb meaning ‘almost not’.

data.chText: 我很少去听音乐会。
data.enText: I hardly ever go to concerts.

data.chText: 我迫切等待着我的生日。
data.enText: I can hardly wait for my birthday.

data.chText: 该词不能代替hard：
data.enText: It cannot be used instead of hard .
I’ve been working hardly today.
She has thought very hardly about her future plans.
It was raining hardly outside.

data.chText: hardly、scarcely和barely均可指刚刚、几乎不，与any和anyone等词以及形容词和动词连用，置于can、could、have、be等与动词的主要部分之间：
data.enText: Hardly , scarcely and barely can all be used to say that something is only just true or possible. They are used with words like any and anyone , with adjectives and verbs, and are placed between can , could , have , be , etc. and the main part of the verb.

data.chText: 这书他们几乎没卖出几本。
data.enText: They have sold scarcely any copies of the book.

data.chText: 我几乎认不出她了。
data.enText: I barely recognized her.

data.chText: 他的话勉强听得见。
data.enText: His words were barely audible.

data.chText: 我几乎不敢相信。
data.enText: I can hardly believe it.
I hardly can believe it.

data.chText: hardly、scarcely和barely为否定词，不应与not或其他否定词连用：
data.enText: Hardly , scarcely and barely are negative words and should not be used with not or other negatives.
I can’t hardly believe it.

data.chText: 亦可用hardly、scarcely和barely表示刚…就…：
data.enText: You can also use hardly , scarcely and barely to say that one thing happens immediately after another.

data.chText: 我们刚在桌子旁坐下，电话铃就响了。
data.enText: We had hardly/scarcely/barely sat down at the table, when the phone rang.

data.chText: 在正式的书面英语中，尤其在文学体中，上述各词可置于句首，然后将主语和动词的位置倒装：
data.enText: In formal, written English, especially in a literary style, these words can be placed at the beginning of the sentence and then the subject and verb are turned around.

data.chText: 我们刚在桌子旁坐下，电话铃就响了。
data.enText: Hardly/Scarcely had we sat down at the table, when the phone rang.

data.chText: 注意：在这类句子中通常用when而非than，亦可用before：
data.enText: Note that you usually use when in these sentences, not than . You can also use before .

data.chText: 我刚一按门铃，门就开了。
data.enText: I scarcely had time to ring the bell before the door opened.

data.chText: no sooner与上述词用法相同，但总与than连用：
data.enText: No sooner can be used in the same way, but is always used with than .

data.chText: 我们刚在桌子旁坐下，电话铃就响了。
data.enText: No sooner had we sat down at the table than the phone rang.

data.chText: hardly和scarcely可表示几乎从不、难得，但barely不这样用：
data.enText: Hardly and scarcely can be used to mean ‘almost never’, but barely is not used in this way.

data.chText: 这些日子她难得见到她父母。
data.enText: She hardly (ever) sees her parents these days.
She barely sees her parents these days.

word_means: 尤用于can或could之后，主要动词之前，强调做某事很难

means: 尤用于can或could之后，主要动词之前，强调做某事很难

ex.chText: 这个小国家几乎没有工业。
ex.enText: This small country has scarcely any industry.

ex.chText: 大厅里人山人海，简直无法走动。
ex.enText: The hall is so crowded that there is scarcely sufficient room for one to move.

ex.chText: 我几乎没有一天不想她。
ex.enText: Scarcely a day goes by when I don't think of her.

synonyms.bx: 指不太充分、不太够，或不能令人满意，强调数量或程度上不足，常与 enough，sufficient，any 等词连用。

ex.chText: 他们的钱刚好够付租金。
ex.enText: They had barely enough money to pay the rent.
She is now barely able to stand.

ex.chText: 那里的村民粗通文字而已。
ex.enText: Barely any of the villagers can read or write.

ex.chText: 经理只略微向她打了个招呼。
ex.enText: The manager barely acknowledged her presence.

synonyms.bx: 指勉强能达到某一数量、程度等，表示肯定意义，强调没有富余。

ex.enText: I'm so tired that I can hardly walk.

ex.chText: 这星期他几乎没睡什么觉。
ex.enText: He's hardly slept at all this week.
There is hardly any milk left.

ex.chText: 如今我已几乎记不得他了。
ex.enText: I can hardly remember him now.

synonyms.bx: 指接近最低限度，几乎没有富余，或指能力上有困难，表示否定意义，常与 any，ever，at all 或情态动词 can 连用。

tr: only a very short time before
example: they could barely hear the speaker
had scarcely rung the bell when the door flew open
would have scarce arrived before she would have found some excuse to leave"- W.B.Yeat
he was hardly more than sixteen years old
they scarcely ever used the emergency generator

value.def: You use hardly to modify a statement when you want to emphasize that it is only a small amount or detail which makes it true, and that therefore it is best to consider the opposite statement as being true.

example.ex: Nick, on the sofa, hardly slept...
example.tran: 尼克在沙发上几乎没睡。

example.ex: He was given hardly 24 hours to pack his bags...
example.tran: 只给了他不到24小时的时间来打点行装。

example.ex: Their two faces were hardly more than eighteen inches apart.
example.tran: 他俩的脸相隔还不到18英寸。

gramarinfo.label: ADV before v, ADV group, oft ADV amount

value.tran: （用于修正作出的陈述，表示不大可能）几乎不，几乎没有

value.def: You use hardly in expressions such as hardly ever ,hardly any, and hardly anyone to mean almost never, almost none, or almost no-one.

example.ex: We ate chips every night, but hardly ever had fish...
example.tran: 我们每晚吃炸薯条，但几乎从不吃鱼。

example.ex: Most of the others were so young they had hardly any experience...
example.tran: 其他人大多都很年轻，几乎没什么经验。
那天晚上几乎没人睡觉。

value.def: You use hardly before a negative statement in order to emphasize that something is usually true or usually happens.

example.ex: Hardly a day goes by without a visit from someone.

value.tran: （用在否定句中构成双重否定，用于强调某事属实或经常发生）几乎不

value.def: When you say you can hardly do something, you are emphasizing that it is very difficult for you to do it.

example.ex: I can hardly believe it's been over eight years since you used to go camping at Cedar Creek...
example.tran: 我几乎无法相信现在距离你过去常常去松溪露营的日子已经有8年多了。

example.ex: My garden was covered with so many butterflies that I could hardly see the flowers.
example.tran: 我的花园里飞舞着很多蝴蝶，我几乎看不见花了。

value.def: If you say hardly had one thing happened when something else happened, you mean that the first event was followed immediately by the second.

example.ex: He had hardly collected the papers on his desk when the door burst open...
example.tran: 他刚收起桌上的文件，门就猛地开了。

example.ex: Hardly had he returned to London when an anonymous well-wisher called to say he was about to be raided by Customs & Excise.
example.tran: 他刚回到伦敦，就有一个不愿透露姓名的好心人打来电话说，他即将面临海关的突击检查。

value.tran: （表示两件事情紧接着发生）刚刚，才

value.def: You use hardly to mean 'not' when you want to suggest that you are expecting your listener or reader to agree with your comment.

example.ex: We have not seen the letter, so we can hardly comment on it...
example.tran: 我们还没有看到这封信，所以无从发表意见。

example.ex: It's hardly surprising his ideas didn't catch on...
example.tran: 他的想法没有被广泛接受，这并不足为奇。

example.ex: The growth rate for 1980-89 was 2.2%. Hardly the stuff of economic miracles.
example.tran: 1980至1989年间的经济增长率是2.2%，算不上什么经济奇迹。

value.tran: （表示希望听者或读者赞同自己）并不，丝毫不

value.def: You use 'hardly' to mean 'no', especially when you want to express surprise or annoyance at a statement that you disagree with.

example.ex: 'They all thought you were marvellous!' —'Well, hardly.'...
example.tran: “他们都认为你很棒！”“哦，不可能吧！”

example.ex: 'We could almost have seen it,' — 'Hardly, darling — in the dark and from a distance of a good hundred feet?'
example.tran: “我们几乎都看到它了。”“不会吧，亲爱的——天那么黑，离得又至少有100英尺呢！”

value.tran: （尤用于对不赞同的说法表示惊奇或不满）不可能，不会吧
